10460.description: You are needed to help facilitate our annual school supply give away and health awareness block party. The street is blocked off to host bounce houses, games, sports etc. The day is busy and on going, so there are several opportunities to serves. Without you this event would not be possible. Thank you in advance for all you do.
10460.title: Back to School Health and Community Awareness Fair

10460.description: Artsmith is a young nonprofit providing arts programming to children in the Bronx. We are currently looking for artists and/or teaching artists for various programs and events our organization runs. Words vs. Pictures: Words vs. Pictures is our visual and literary arts program serving elementary and middle school students. The program is designed to teach students ways to express themselves and explore important topics using various writing and art methods. We are looking for artists/teaching artists that can teach one or more visual arts disciplines - drawing/sketching, painting, photography, sculpture, etc. The program meets once per week on Saturday afternoons. Contact us whether you'd like to teach a single class or make a longer commitment. Paint and Sip: Our paint and sips are fundraisers that are held at local Bronx breweries or restaurants. If you are a painter interested in leading these events please contact us. We will provide the necessary materials for the participants. At Artsmith, we are dedicated to providing arts education to young people in the Bronx who have little or no opportunity to experience the arts. We know that the arts provide our students with a great and safe place to learn creativity, experiment and take risks, develop discipline, and build confidence. Arts education should not be a question of access. You must believe in this mission to volunteer with us! Email resume and 2-3 art samples to tricia.smith@artsmith.org.
10460.title: Artist/Teaching Artist

10460.description: There is a tremendous need, especially for high-risk youth in low-income neighborhoods in The Bronx municipality, for programs that provide activities and support for children during the after school hours and throughout the summer and ACN has stepped up to take the responsibility in addressing this problem through our new initiative (ACN YOUTH CAPACITY BUILDING) Project. In 1998, the Children’s Defense Fund reported that violent crime by young people ages 10-17 peaks between 3 and 7 PM; children and teens in poor neighborhoods are struggling for direction and positive opportunities are needed to keep them safe and on-track; a great majority of all American fourth graders cannot read or do math at grade level, including more than five of six black children. In addition, a study published in Pediatrics magazine found that eighth graders who were left alone after school reported greater use of cigarettes, marijuana, and alcohol than those in adult-supervised settings. Current research indicates that supervised after-school and summer programs not only keep children safe and out of trouble, they also significantly improve their academic achievement. PROJECT DESCRIPTION Teaching high-risk, inner-city Youth the skills to become successful in life is at the core of the ACN SUMMER YOUTH CAPACITY BUILDING program. The Four(4) major components of the program are: *Homework Assistance through tutoring, mentoring and Use of Computer labs. *Nutrition Education to promote healthy lifestyles and Combat Obesity. *Life Skills which are integrated throughout all phases of the program. *Soccer Instructions where participants engage in fun physical fitness, enjoy the camaraderie of playing in a soccer team format with friends and peers, and learn to become responsible adolescents and adults. The summer After-School Program- will serve approximately 600 children which includes academic tutoring five(5) hours per week and Soccer Instruction, Health and life skills education ten(10) hours per week. Participants will receive Soccer Instruction in professional settings and practice skills in team format play. They will learn about the rules of the game, etiquette, sportsmanship, positive attitudes, fair play, self-esteem, taking responsibility for choices and management of emotions. These life skills are integrated throughout the Soccer program, and instructors routinely demonstrate how they apply to situations in all aspects of life. Nutrition and Healthy lifestyles are stressed both in the Classroom setting and on the Soccer Field. Healthy Snacks will be provided. The ACN YOUTH CAPACITY BUILDING program is Fortunate to have a corpse of Volunteers willing to dedicate to the program and are available to work with the children on improving their academic skills. Seeking Volunteers from some of the community based Universities/colleges who will take an active role in the homework area, working individually with the students using current homework assignments. In the computer lab, Volunteer tutors will help the students improve their keyboarding skills and show them how to use the computer for research. They will read aloud with the students and give quizzes on tapes and videos to improve comprehension. When the college/university students volunteers are not on campus, volunteers from local Churches will assume the role of tutors. Incentives will be awarded to the participants based on attendance, good behavior and general attitude.
10460.title: ACN YOUTH CAPACITY BUILDING PROJECT

10305.description: Thursday, August 9th|Staten Island|6:00pm-9:00pm Help us celebrate the summer at Geller House, a residence for children, with an evening of fun activities and snacks provided by the Staten Island community.
10305.title: Summer fun at Geller House!

10301.description: We are an agency that serves homebound older adults. Our mission is to keep them in their homes for as long as possible. Many of them are socially isolated and the only person they see each day is the driver who comes to drop off their meals on wheels. This does not provide the socialization they so desperately need. This is why we need you to be a friend to an older adult. To have a cup of coffee, tea, play cards, take a walk and/or just chat. We only ask for an hour per week. Volunteers can be from 18 to 80. To find out more about this opportunity please contact Rosanne McAllister 718-981-6226 ext. 141.
10301.title: Staten Island Volunteers needed to Brighten the Lives of Seniors.
10301.org: COMMUNITY AGENCY FOR SENIOR CITIZENS INC

10301.description: We have a lovely wheelchair bound senior who spends most of her days alone. This Client does not have much of a family. She loves old movies, and also loves to knit and crochet (she can even teach you!). She has 2 very friendly dogs but would love someone to come and chat with her and even sharpen her computer skills. If you can get to Travis and can spare one hour per week, please contact Rosanne McAllister at 718 981-6226, ext 141 for further information. Thanks in advance for your kindness. Your kindness will benefit someone who is alone and isolated.
10301.title: STATEN ISLANDERS!  Can you travel to Travis?
10301.org: COMMUNITY AGENCY FOR SENIOR CITIZENS INC

10301.description: We are Community Agency for Senior Citizens, Inc. We have been in Staten Island for over 40 years. We only serve Older Adults. The program is called the Friendly Visiting Program. The program began in January/2017. We look to \"Match\" you with an Older Adult. The program asks that you spend one hour in the Client's home. While visiting the Client, you can have a cup of coffee/tea, play a table top game, cards, read a book together, watch a movie. The visit is what you both decide upon. This is a building block relationship. So far, many of our \"Match's\" have become good friends and look forward to these weekly visits. Your volunteering brings much happiness to someone who is alone and isolated.
10301.title: Do You Want to Brighten Someone's Day? Volunteer's Are the Sunshine that Homebound Adult's Need
10301.org: COMMUNITY AGENCY FOR SENIOR CITIZENS INC

10028.description: We are in need of a CPR Instructor to teach some of the mothers of Nurse-Family Partnership. NFP sends specially trained nurses to do home visits with low-income first time mothers from the time they are pregnant until their babies are 2 years of age. We at Friends of NYC Nurse-Family Partnershipi arrange various learning opportunities for the mothers at sites in the 5 boroughs. As funds are extremely limited, we need a volunteer to do a one-hour class in CPR. The moms do not need to be certified. They want to learn CPR for babies and toddlers as well as the fundamentals for preventing choking. If you have some time to spare for a very worthy cause, please contact us and let us know your credentials.
10028.title: CPR INSTRUCTOR
10028.org: FRIENDS OF NEW YORK CITY NURSE FAMILY PARTNERSHIP INC

10028.description: Do you have a few hours to spend helping us devlop programs for young mothers and their babies? The mission of Friends of NYC Nurse-Family Partnereship is to improve the lives of babies and their mothers by providing enhanced benefits for the nationally renowned Nurse-Family Partnership. NFP sends registered nurses to make regular visits to first-time, low-income mothers, from the time the mothers are pregnant until their babies are 2. Friends of NYC NFP is developing and leading LEAP (Learn, Eat, and Play) programs which help the mothers meet and socialize with other young moms while learning about nutrition, finance, making toys out of household objects and much more. We need VOLUNTEERS who can help us create interesting play times for the babies. We'd like to: Showing mothers the importance of interactions with their baby Teach about a rich learning environment Show exercises which will allow babies to explore and learn Programs are held around midday during the week at locations in the boroughs of NYC. If interested, please send resume and phone number.
10028.title: Pre-School Teacher
10028.org: FRIENDS OF NEW YORK CITY NURSE FAMILY PARTNERSHIP INC

10028.description: Are you a singer, guitar player, or have other musical talents appropriate for young mothers and their babies? The babies are all under 2 years of age. If you have appropriate musical experience and talent and would like to entertain in such a situation and you are available week days, we would like to hear from you. Events typically last 2-3 hours; frequency would be once a quarter or more. Please send a note describing your musical background;experience with very young children a big plus. SEND YOUR RESUME AND PHONE NUMBER.
10028.title: Guitarist or Keyboard Player for Mother/Baby Events
10028.org: FRIENDS OF NEW YORK CITY NURSE FAMILY PARTNERSHIP INC

10029.description: We're looking for several people to volunteer with our Meals on Wheels program on Saturday, August 11th! We welcome both individual volunteers and small groups. For over 40 years, Union Settlement has provided Meals on Wheels to East Harlem's older residents that are often economically struggling and living alone. Our Meals on Wheels program currently serves approximately 450 homebound seniors each day. Prior to the volunteer date, volunteers will be sent a short training video and brief quiz to help prepare them for participation with Meals on Wheels. Volunteers will help pack hot and cold meals and then join staff on deliveries where they will get to hand out meals to our clients and interact with the East Harlem community. Volunteers are not required to have a driver's license or own a car. When: Saturday, August 11th from 8:30am to 12:30pm Where: Jefferson Senior Center in East Harlem Interested individuals or groups should email volunteers@unionsettlement.org with the subject line \"Saturday, August 11th Meals on Wheels Volunteer\".
10029.title: Volunteer with Meals on Wheels on Saturday, August 11th!

10029.description: DREAM, an award winning youth development program, is seeking volunteer T-ball coaches to work with youth ages 5-7 in practices and games. Coaches teach T-ball and provide youth with opportunities to play, learn and grow; inspiring them to recognize their potential and realize their dreams. Each coach serves as a member of a small coaching staff. There are powerful rewards gained from the DREAM coaching experience. DREAM volunteer coaches can have a direct and noticeable impact on the positive development of the youth they coach. The ideal candidate is passionate about youth development, has experience working with youth, and can commit to attending six Saturday practices and games in July/August, as well as a one-day pre-season coaches training in June. Roles and Responsibilities: Guide a team of 16-18 youth through practices and games; Ensure youth safety on the field; Provide a fun and positive, team-based environment; Attend all practices and games on six Saturdays in July and August. Qualifications: Passionate about youth development; Understand the power of teamwork; Have the ability to create a positive, team-based environment focused on teaching T-ball; Organized, energetic and flexible; Skilled communicators; Experience in baseball/softball a plus; Able to commit to six Saturdays, in July and August; At least 18 years of age. Hours: Coaches conduct practices and games for an hour and a half on six Saturday mornings or afternoons from 7/7/18 to 8/11/18. Coaches must be able to commit to attend all six Saturday coaching sessions during the summer, as well as the coach training day in June. DREAM provides equal opportunity for all volunteers.
10029.title: Volunteer T-Ball Coaches!

10029.description: This is a wonderful opportunity to support school staff and elementary school students during lunchtime and recess from 10:30-11:30 am. Students eat in cafeteria from 10:30-11:00 am then go out to the school yard to play from 11-11:30 am. We are looking persons who can supervise students at the lunch table then lead them to the yard and facilitate organized play. We think of organized play broadly so it can include any sports, team building games, dance, art or any other. We will supply any equipment needed. This opportunity is for the entire school year but we are looking to place a few volunteers so if you can not commit to the full school year please let us know how many months you can commit to.
10029.title: Facilitate Elementary School Organized Play (Lunchtime)
10029.org: Ps 108 Assemblyman Angelo Del Toro Educational Com

10029.description: Dear Manhattan and Queens folks, On behalf of the Mount Sinai Sexual Assault and Violence Intervention (SAVI) Program, I wanted to invite you to join us in eradicating sexual and intimate partner violence from our communities. New York City needs you! By joining our roster of volunteer Emergency Department (ED) Advocates it is possible to have an impact. An ED Advocate is trained to provide support and advocacy for survivors in emergency departments, so they don’t have to face the difficult decisions, emotions and follow-up procedures alone. SAVI ED Advocates helped more than 500 survivors in New York City Emergency Departments last year- that’s almost 2 survivors a day! We hope you or someone you know may be interested in becoming a Volunteer Emergency Department Advocate. Those interested should visit https://tinyurl.com/savirecruit for information and the application. If you have any questions please call (212) 423-2140 or email savi@mssm.edu for the next steps. In your email please include your telephone number and the general best day(s) and time(s) to reach you at that number. Interviews will be held from July - October and those accepted into the program will begin training in October. More information is also available at our website: please visit www.mssm.edu/savi . Thank you so much for your help and we hope to hear from you! Your friends at The Mount Sinai SAVI Team
10029.title: Help Survivors of Sexual and Intimate Partner Violence - Manhattan and Queens Residents Needed!

10026.description: Each Wednesday, we prep & serve a simple vegetarian meal offering in Central Harlem for anyone who needs a meal. One can help cook and/or serve and/or clean up. Time commitment is flexible: 2 & 1/2 hours to prep/cook, 1 hour to set up/serve, 1 hour clean up. One can help out with any part of the meal. Any level of skill is accepted.
10026.title: Volunteer To Cook & Serve Every Wednesday

10027.description: Morningside Area Alliance will be joining Grant Houses during their annual Family Day celebration. We are seeking a volunteer to assist us throughout the day (11:00AM - 5:00PM). Volunteer activities include: Sharing community information, assisting with the setup/breakdown of our booth, taking photographs, and helping kids with arts & crafts. Morningside Area Alliance is a 65 year old organization dedicated to supporting this community’s academic, cultural, and religious institutions. This community-based event is a great way to learn about this incredible neighborhood.
10027.title: Community Outreach at Grant Houses Family Day

10027.description: The Sakura Park Festival is back in Morningside Heights for its second year! Neighbors of every age will enjoy the sounds, moves, and tastes of our global community in the beautiful Sakura Park and on West 122nd Street between Claremont and Riverside. Volunteer Information: Volunteers will share community information, assist with event setup/breakdown, and direct participants. Volunteers will be split into three time slots. 10:00AM - 1:30PM, 1:30PM - 5:00PM, and 5:00PM - 8:30PM. 10:00AM volunteers may be required to meet at our office (only a few blocks from the events site). Afternoon volunteers may meet us at Sakura Park during the festival. Please specify the time slot you are interested in. There will be FREE FOOD available for volunteers. For more information, visit the Eventbrite page: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/sakura-park-festival-tickets-36027957591 You can also find us on Facebook & Twitter for updates on the upcoming event: https://www.facebook.com/sakuraparkfestival/ https://twitter.com/sakuraparkfest
10027.title: Community Outreach at 2018 Sakura Park Festival

10027.description: We are looking for volunteers to welcome the riders home at the end of their 3 day biking journey from Cooperstown to New York. We have a variety of opportunities during our celebratory closing ceremony at Grants Tomb National Monument on the Upper West Side.
10027.title: Volunteer for Braking AIDS Ride 2018!

10027.description: Artistic Noise Board of Directors Job Posting Job Description: As we enter our 18th year at Artistic Noise we are seeking new board members to support our organization’s growth. From our roots as a small program fiscally sponsored by an umbrella non-profit at Boston College, we have grown to become an independent 501(c)(3) organization. We moved from the \"incubator\" to \"startup\" phase in 2010, and now are building out more robust infrastructure to ensure we can offer our programs to more youth in need. Our mission is narrowly focused and we are experts at the work we do having refined our programmatic model over our 18 years. That said, we need our board to support the business of running a nonprofit, by Sharing their professional expertise and advice, Providing philanthropic support, Actively connecting Artistic Noise to the right people, resources, and partnerships. We ask that board members make a commitment of 3 years to Artistic Noise and participate in quarterly board meetings and committee meetings as needed. Candidates should be located in the Greater Boston or NYC areas. Desired Qualifications and Responsibilities: Participate in at least one of the standing committees (Governance, Finance, Development, Strategic Planning) Actively fundraise for the organization through your personal giving, networks, and more broadly. Have 3+ years experience in either the nonprofit or corporate sectors. Have experience/expertise in at least one of the following areas: finance, accounting, marketing, development, public relations, law. Some prior board experience preferred, but not required. This is a volunteer, unpaid position. Believe in the mission of Artistic Noise. About Artistic Noise: Mission and Purpose Artistic Noise exists to bring the freedom and power of artistic practice to young people who are incarcerated, on probation, or otherwise involved in the justice system. Through visual arts and entrepreneurship programs in Massachusetts and New York, our youth artists give voice to their experiences, build community through collaborative projects, and learn valuable life and job skills. Artistic Noise creates safe spaces where court-involved youth can be seen, heard and supported on their path to adulthood. We believe the practice of making art offers opportunities for young people and communities to transform. About our Programs By working with youth both in state custody and back in the community, Artistic Noise provides continuity for young people who are often experiencing trauma and upheaval in their lives. Our staff of teaching artists and licensed art therapists works with our participants to create safe, challenging spaces for creative expression. Using a variety of artistic mediums, youth explore themes such as friendship, loss, sexual violence, community, freedom, identity and their dreams for the future. This structured artmaking fosters critical thinking and problem solving skills that are beneficial to the teens' healthy psychological development. https://www.artisticnoise.org/ How to apply: Please submit your resume/cover letter to tamara.scarlett@artisticnoise.com and/or Amanda.holm@artisticnoise.com
10027.title: Artistic Noise seeks new member for Board of Directors

10027.description: Market Access Program Intern Start Small Think Big (Start Small) is a not-for-profit organization located in Harlem. Our mission is to help under resourced individuals build and sustain thriving businesses in order to increase their personal financial security and stimulate economic activity in underserved communities in New York City. We believe that entrepreneurship results in increased innovation and sustained economic growth for everyone, in particular, those most traditionally marginalized. The Market Access Program Intern will work with the Marketing Program Manager to assist our entrepreneurs with marketing and sales business needs. This includes developing resource guides, learning more about sales opportunities in NYC and online, and supporting our communications team with a social media strategy. Job Responsibilities shall include, but are not limited to: Assist in managing Start Small Think Big social media platforms, including creating and posting content, identifying influencers in the space, and responding to comments and questions received from entrepreneurs. Research and develop informative resource guides focused on assisting entrepreneurs in identifying and addressing business challenges and community resources necessary to increase business success. Support the Marketing Program Manager in delivering services, via workshops, consultations, and project-based relationships, this includes managing logistics of events, coordinating entrepreneur attendance, and all necessary follow-up calls. Assist in developing the evaluation rubrics used by volunteer marketing experts to help entrepreneurs identify weaknesses in their current marketing practices. Preferred Skills/Qualifications: Current undergraduate student with strong interest in writing, social media, and communications, nonprofit program management, or other related disciplines. High level of computer proficiency including familiarity with Google Applications, social media (Facebook, Instagram and Twitter) and MS Office. Knowledge of programs: Buffer and Canva a plus. Demonstrated commitment to inclusive community/economic development, social and economic justice work, and/or anti-poverty work. Excellent verbal and written communication skills, time management, and interpersonal skills; Highly organized, creative and self-motivated; a strong problem-solver and analytical/critical thinker; and Experience working in low-income and/or immigrant communities. TO APPLY: Submit resume to: Eliza Edge, Market Access Program Manager at eliza@startsmallthinkbig.org (include subject line: \"[your name] Market Access Program Intern.\" This position is unpaid, but may be used for course credit where appropriate. Minimum of 20 hours/week at our office. Days are flexible. Start Small Think Big is an equal opportunity employer with a standing policy of nondiscrimination. This means that all qualified persons are accorded an equal opportunity for employment or promotion without regard to actual or perceived race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, disability, medical condition, marital status, sex, age, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, family responsibility, personal appearance, genetic information, matriculation, or political affiliation.
10027.title: Market Access Program Intern - Fall

11225.description: This program is for teens and college students looking for a seasonal volunteer opportunity. Based in the Prospect Park Zoo's Education Department, Discovery Guides are seasonal volunteers (14 - 22) who receive training in customer service and basic interpretation. Discovery Guides focus on a select group of visitor experiences and, in turn, gain experience with teaching, leadership, public speaking, and learn about animals and the wild places they inhabit! Discovery Guides will: Interact with children, families, and general visitors at select exhibits and educational activities around the zoo Help out with zoo birthday parties on weekends Interact with children in the Discovery Center and at our Nature Playscape Participate in the Wildlife Conservation Society's Conservation Action campaigns We are currently recruiting youth for Summer 2018. Training will be June 10, 17, 24, 28 & 29. Volunteers must commit to two full days per week for the summer season. Applications will be available on our website in March, and are due by May 1, 2018. To request an application sooner, email the Volunteer Coordinator at ppzvolunteer@wcs.org.
11225.title: Summer Discovery Guide

10025.description: Inspire Women to Travel Solo and deconstruct your expereince with others! Do you have useful tips, tricks, or special interests that will inspire people to hit the road? Can you discuss how your positionality impacted your experience traveling solo? If so, we’d love you to be a presenter at one of our monthly travel workshops. Presentations are free and open to the public, helping educate travelers about the benefits of travel, and how they may be perceived. Speakers will work with the Hostelling International USA Education Coordinator to: Create a brief one paragraph description of your travel experience that captures the essence of your travels Build an interactive 5 slide presentation with a slide show, food or anything you think helps the presentation resonate with attendees Deliver presentation to a group of about 5 up to 30 people, including questions from the audience. Workshops are held either at the New York Hostel or can be presented remotely at one of our partner sites. Presenters are welcome to create unique presentations of their own, or incorporate additional elements that will be useful. Sample presentations and general presentation tips are provided to all prospective travel presenters. Supporting our Mission: The travel workshop presenter, through savvy travel tips and cultural learning recommendations, helps inspires a genuine understanding of people, places and cultures for a more respectful and empathetic world. Requirements: Public speaking and presentation skills Passion for travel and teaching others to travel 2 hours per program Presenter must be available to present during the evening, typically on Wednesdays or Thursdays. To Apply: Please email Education Coordinator, Indigo Goodson at indigo.goodson@hiusa.org and visit http://www.volunteers.hiusa.org to fill out a form. Please provide: Best telephone number you can be reached for initial screening interview and best hours to reach you.
10025.title: Be a Women Traveling Solo 101 Presenter at HI NY!

10025.description: Whether you're great, good or fair at Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM), you can help make an impact on inner-city youth. Here's how: The Parris Foundation S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program has returned for the Summer 2018 session. The program began after a successful summer pilot in 2012, and our subsequent programs have grown to continue to serve middle school students and high school students . With the growing impact on the community, we need your support to continue to bring STEM to our middle school and high school youth throughout New York City. As we expand to more locations to serve more youth, there is a growing need for volunteers! How we do it: The Parris Foundation curriculum combines innovative and interactive software and teaching techniques with hand-ons interdisciplinary experiments and activities to keep our students engaged with their passion for science and math! About The Parris Foundation: The Parris Foundation is dedicated to promoting educational opportunities and fostering awareness in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) through scholarships and community outreach programs. The Parris Foundation's S.T.E.M.ulating Minds: Weekend Enrichment Programs provide extended learning opportunities to supplement and enhance in-school learning.
10025.title: Summer 2018 - S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program

10025.description: The New Jewiish Home, Manhattan Division has a wide variety of opportunities for high school and college students to volunteer with over the summer vacation. Opportunities vary and we will try our best to meet your interest Opportunities include but not limited to: Recreation Assistant (Bingo, Games, Exercise, Arts & Crafts, Nail Spa) Pharamacy (selective, limited spots) Library Assistant (upkeep of shelving, assisting book selections, assisting computer users) Clerical/Office Assistant Please apply online at the following link: https://www.volgistics.com/ex/portal.dll/ap?ap=1114206372 Please mention Volunteer Match & Summer Volunteering in your application If you have any questions - Please contact Jessica at JSinovoi@jewishhome.org
10025.title: Summer Volunteer at The New Jewish Home (HS & College students)
10025.org: The New Jewish Home, Manhattan Division

10022.description: Active Plus is an organization with a goal to inspire, motivate, and educate people of all ages to live a healthy and active lifestyle. On Saturday, September 8th, 2018, we will be hosting our inaugural fundraiser #beActivePlus Day at Columbia University. The fundraiser will be centered around fitness and nutrition. From 9:00 am-11:00 am our partners at Equinox will be conducting adult group fitness classes. 11222.description: Transportation Alternatives (T.A.) is holding the 29th Annual NYC Century Bike Tour on September 9th, 2018. With multiple routes of 15, 35, 55, 75 and 100 miles, to accommodate all skill levels from tricycles to time-trialists, the Century is always a wonderful event that brings together the NYC bicycling community to enjoy our great city. With thousands of cyclists hitting the streets, T.A. is seeking volunteers to help us make the day a success. With rest stops in each of the boroughs, help is needed in YOUR neighborhood. All volunteer duties are extremely safe and simple, including setting up/breaking down tents, checking riders in for the tour, and distributing food/water -- a great opportunity for families to come out and have fun by helping the community. There are several 4-5 hours shifts throughout the day, an easy commitment given you will be working in some of NYC's finest parks! We also have opportunities that will allow you to ride the tour itself by volunteering as a bike marshal. All volunteers are entitled to an official Tour t-shirt and snacks will also be provided. For more information, please see www.nyccentury.org. INTERESTED??? Click this link - https://tinyurl.com/ya8jpjzg Safe riding, we'll see you on the road!!

07424.description: Welcome to the Inaugural Gray Mud Run! We thank you for supporting the National Brain Tumor Society’s efforts to find a cure for brain tumors and improve the quality of life and treatment options for those living with a Brain Tumor. This is the first event established in Northern New Jersey to serve the brain tumor community (and the first of it’s kind for NBTS)... And we are so excited to be here! The Gray Mud Run is a family friendly fun run and muddy obstacle course. The Adult course is a 5K and the Kids course is a 3K. This event was inspired by the life and brain tumor journey of Lindsay Gray. Beloved daughter, sister, friend and fearless NJ State Trooper. We are working together with the NJ State Troopers to reach the entire Tri-State area brain tumor community with this event and look forward to having a remarkable turn out! We need volunteers for many different jobs... From manning obstacles to running registration, and everything inbetween. So let's have a conversation so we can decide what would be the right fit for you! Looking forward to connecting! Suzanne
07424.title: Gray Mud Run

11743.description: Who doesn't love the warmth and unconditional love from a beautiful four legged furry pet? If you love dogs, and I mean, really love dogs then you can be part of a rewarding experience. Our exclusive Pet Therapy program is currently looking for chaperones. We have committed pet therapy handlers who bring their trained and certified dogs to the hospital to visit our patients. As a chaperone you will be . . . escorting the handler and dog to the patient floors on various units. engaging and interact with our patients & families and wonderful caregivers. providing hand sanitizer to all who pet the dog. greeting patients and introducing the pet handler and pet therapy dog. able to commit to one day a week for a maximum of 2 hours, usually not more than an hour. The presence of a dog in a hospital setting allows the patients to feel more at home, as they do play a small part of the healing process. The immediate gratification you will see on the patients' and staffs' faces when they are interacting with the dog is truly amazing. There are known benefits for pet therapy visits . . . improves mood and overall well-being decreases stress and anxiety lowers blood pressure lets patients reminisce about their own animals If you are interested in volunteering in our program, please contact me for an interview. Alice Messina Patient Liaison Pet Therapy Coordinator 631-351-2399 amessina2@northwell.edu
11743.title: Pet Therapy Chaperone

07018.description: The Pearl Club has a mission to educate, empower and support young women to overcome poverty by fostering advanced educational pursuit. Through our programming, The Pearl Club University, we strive to empower young women to overcome poverty by attaining a post-secondary degree. The position of the Board of Directors is a voluntary position that serves as the leadership, sustainability and growth of the organization. In this role, there are three focuses: Strategic Oversight: approve annual budgets, strategic plans and review and measure outcomes; provide strategic leadership Sustainability: actively participate in fundraising initiatives, see this as a philanthropic priority and assist in identifying board members and contribute to the annual performance of ED Commitment: actively participate and attend board meetings and take a proactive approach to the growth of the organization Within these three focuses, the Board of Directors is responsible for the following: Actively attend board meetings, including preparing for meetings Strong commitment to the organization's mission and purpose by acting as a brand ambassador and connecting/extending the organization to your network and beyond Open, honest and unbiased communication Thorough decision making that aligns with the mission, is student- and future-focused Actively participate in board fundraising goals and organizational fundraising initiatives Think outside of the box to produce outcomes, develop relationships, generate partnerships and provide opportunities for young women Stay current on important trends that relate to their expertise as it relates to the growth and success of the organization Be inspired to share their involvement with their networks to garner support and build relationships, including inviting them to all events and providing contacts to include in our email distribution lists Willingness to step out of comfort zone to produce outcomes, including trainings and professional development We are looking for someone with the following: Experience launching and building a new brand/organization Interest in growing a sustainable organization Connected to Education + corporations Experience with Fundraising, Leading and planning initiatives Provide strategic leadership experience A desire to be hands-on w/high level of initiative
07018.title: Join Our Board of Directors

In addition, you would support and coordinate external activities such as volunteer opportunities, events and trips and more Programming and Student Engagement Volunteers should commit for at least 6 months and commit to up to 5 hours a week depending on projects and tasks.

10310.description: A Let’s Get Ready Access Coach is a volunteer position for current undergraduate college students or recent graduates interested in supporting high school students from low-income households through SAT preparation and college admissions guidance, many of whom will be the first generation to attend college. Let’s Get Ready Coaches are a part of a network of approximately 1,000 college students per year working together to help students build confidence to tackle the SAT and get to and through college. Coaches are expected to commit to: At least one night a week (3 hours) of direct tutoring and mentoring with a group of 5-7 high school students 1.5 hours a week to prepare for each week’s lesson and to communicate with students about homework questions, attendance reminders, and other support. Let’s Get Ready provides training and ongoing support for all of its Coaches. Initial training is based around the SAT, its structure, and how to effectively engage a classroom of high school students. Secondary trainings are conducted by Let’s Get Ready Site Directors and focus on how to improve and give Coaches a chance to highlight some aspects of their role that are going really well. Throughout programming, Let’s Get Ready staff supports Coaches with a variety of resources and professional development opportunities as well as in-person observations and feedback. Let’s Get Ready also provides lesson plans for each week of programming. We encourage coaches to be innovative and creative when implementing lesson plans and tailoring classes to the skill level of the students. Position Responsibilities: Classroom Management and SAT Preparation Provide SAT preparation (either Math or Writing and Language) to a group of 5 to 7 high school students from low-income families Use classroom management techniques to keep students engaged in each lesson Prepare lessons for each class night, taking into account student needs and areas of growth Communication and Relationship Building Consistently communicate with students outside of class to help with homework completion and overall engagement in the program Work effectively with Site Directors and fellow Coaches throughout the program to build a strong network of leadership for your students Engage with all students throughout programming to not only build, but maintain strong relationships Help foster a college success culture through Let’s Get Ready’s College Choice curriculum College Admission Support Engage students in conversations centered around college by guiding them through the College Choice Checklist Encourage a college-going culture in the classroom Lead weekly activities and discussion about the college admissions process Support the initial phases of developing a college essay Who we look for: Let’s Get Ready seeks passionate individuals who are committed to the mission of providing educational resources and support to all students. Our Coaches are team players, focused on doing whatever it takes to help students gain the confidence that is needed to begin the college-going process. Questions? Contact zsmolen@letsgetready.org. Apply online at https://www.tfaforms.com/4658529
10310.title: Calling all college students who are passionate about education & mentorship!

10562.description: What does the Parent Child Together Program Do? Parent Child Together provides parents with peer-to-peer learning opportunities with a focus on positive parenting skills, early childhood development and school readiness. While the parents learn, the children participate in activities within the classroom covering shapes, colors, numbers, letters, pre literacy concepts as well as helping them gain the social emotional and self regulation skills needed prior to entering Kindergarten. What do the Volunteers Do? In the first hour the parents and children work separately and at this point, staff and volunteers help the children with separation and also carrying out the activities for the hour. In the second hour, parents and children come together for activities and the role of the staff and volunteers at this point, is to model techniques for struggling parents and assist when a parent has more than one child in the program. We ask for a minimum commitment of 6 months - if possible (there is flexibility for vacations etc.)
10562.title: Parent Child Together program volunteer in Ossining

10018.description: Global Green is seeking help from a volunteer with experience in financial modeling to contribute to our work with supporting cities in planning for increased resource efficiency and reduction of waste materials. The use of wastewater treatment plants for \"co-digesting\" food waste allows for existing infrastructure, and the creation of biogas from the waste. Biogas can be used to generate electricity or transport fuel, and the compost or digestate by-product is used as a fertilizer. This is a part of a larger project. Links with more information are provided below: Resilience Planning: https://www.globalgreen.org/blog/xl8faarys9e758zfyj3pa58raddm5p Circular Economy Planning: https://www.globalgreen.org/blog/m9dt388wwr55brtem28fn32fgbfz89 The volunteer will receive information from Global Green collected from sources including case studies of cities currently creating biogas from food waste, and from an EPA excel tool. After an initial meeting the volunteer will prepare a basic financial model that goes deeper into cash flow projections for different project types and sizes over a 5, 10 and 20 year period. Results will be explained to the Global Green team, and any needed additional research to complete the model and its assumptions will be provided by Global Green.
10018.title: NYC Based Financial Modeling Volunteer Needed for Biogas Project
10018.org: Coalition for Resource Recovery Global Green USA

10018.description: Its important that in order to address the significant environmental challenges before us that we measure and report on our impact as a society. In our work with cities and communities, Global Green has crafted some impact goals and is using to communicate these goals internally, within our Board and also in external materials such as newsletters and on our website. Furthermore, by having cohesive national impact goals this will enable us to better coordinate across our 4 offices in Los Angeles, NYC, New Orleans and DC. We're seeking help from a graphic design professional to illustrate the impact goals below. These can be either done in an infographic style or more of a conceptual / symbolic style. Global Green's staff will meet with the volunteer in person (if in NYC) or by phone and discuss a strategy and then the volunteer will create the design. The graphics will be used for a number of purposes including internal communications, in our newsletter, on globalgreen.org and in annual reports or other reporting.
10018.title: NYC Graphic Design Volunteer Needed to Illustrate Measurable Impact Goals
10018.org: Coalition for Resource Recovery Global Green USA

10018.description: Fiver Children's Foundation is seeking two (2) efficient and detail-oriented Database Administrative Volunteers to join their team! Fiver;s Database Administrative Volunteers ill work with Fiver's Operations and Accounting Department i a fast-paced work environment. Responsibilities for this position include but or not limited to, recording important information about the participants who attended and will attend Camp Fiver, Fiver's Summer Residential Program. This information is crucial when evaluating the success of Camp Fiver, evaluating and seeking funding, scheduling of Camp Programs, and maintaining pertinent contact information about Fiver Families. Fiver's Database Administrative Volunteers will assist Fiver in making a positive impact on the lives of youth throughout New York City and Central New York by successfully fulfilling the responsibilities of the volunteer position. Responsibilities include: Review Camp Fiver 2018 Applications and Health Forms Enter and update information collected from Fiver's 2018 Camp Applications Check for accuracy regarding addresses, Program Stages and assigned Session for each participant Conduct outreach for outstanding documents Any additional tasks related to this position as assigned Requirements for this position: Detail oriented Self-starter who can execute assignments independently A strong work ethic and sets high standards for his/her/their own work Strong organizational skills Analytical skills Experience with data entry and Excel preferred Language Skills Required: Spanish speaking preferred, but not required Fiver's Administrative Volunteers will: Attend a training on the software that will be used throughout the volunteer position Play a crucial role in a nonprofit that makes a 10-year commitment to youth throughout New York City and central New York and empowers them to make ethical and healthy life choices, become engaged citizens, and succeed in school, careers, and life. Be a member of a vibrant and divers team of staff members and volunteers Develop professionally through this volunteer position Assist Fiver Children's Foundation with the organization of information regarding Fiver participants who attended and will be attending Camp Fiver this summer Time Commitment: Must be able to commit a minimum of 10 - 15 hours on Monday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday Dates: May 2018 - August 2018 If you are interested in this volunteer opportunity, please email your resume to casie@fiver.org.

10012.description: About Housing Works: Housing Works is a healing community of people living with and affected by HIV/AIDS. Our mission is to end the dual crises of homelessness and AIDS through relentless advocacy, the provision of lifesaving services, and entrepreneurial businesses that sustain our efforts. About the position: We are looking for a volunteer/intern to help us secure in-kind donations for our thrift shops, for the thrifts special events, and for Housing Works’ annual Fashion for Action Fundraiser in November. We need your help to: Secure product donations for stores and for special events Conduct research for prospective donors (such as interior designers, furniture/houseware companies, fashion designers, clothing, shoe and accessory companies) Send e-mails and conduct follow-up calls (must be comfortable making cold calls) Record and track incoming donations using our online database, Salesforce Assist with event prep as needed Attend the events as a volunteer and see the finished product! Please apply if you are: Detail oriented Experienced with basic computer programs (Microsoft Word and Excel) Excited by getting hands-on experience in a nonprofit environment A great communicator (both written and spoken) What you get in return: Firsthand exposure to in-kind fundraising Experience working with fun people in an awesome thrift shop environment Understanding of how to use CRM software (we will train you on your first day) School credit (if applicable) 25% off in the Housing Works SoHo Thrift Shop! Hours & Location: 4 months beginning in August, with the opportunity to extend Available to work 10-15 hours per week during 9am-6pm time frame (any days Monday through Friday - we will work with your schedule) Our office is located at 584 Broadway, New York, NY 10012 If you are interested in this opportunity, please send an email to volunteer@housingworks.org with both a resume and cover letter. Inquiries submitted through VolunteerMatch will not be accepted.
10012.title: Seeking Special Events and Development Intern

10011.description: The Children’s Tumor Foundation is a non-profit organization dedicated to funding critical research that will one day end neurofibromatosis. In addition to benefiting those who live with NF, this research is also shedding new light on several forms of cancer, brain tumors, bone abnormalities, and learning disabilities, ultimately benefiting the broader community. The Children’s Tumor Foundation also supports people living with NF and their families with accurate, current and readily accessible information, and assists in the development of clinical centers to create better access to quality healthcare. We are in need of several committee members to join our team of NF Walk Organizers! The role of the committee member may be: To partner with and support the event chair in planning the event within the community. Help motivate, recruit and retain the participants. Communicate with the event Chair on a regular basis and be proactive in the community promoting the event. Assist with logistics and pre-event planning. Securing donations for a raffle, picnic and fundraising. Recruit and organize event-day volunteers. Assist with event-day activity planning and management and post event wrap up. Join the CTF Volunteer Team and see what a difference one person can make! Event site: https://join.ctf.org/event/2018-nf-walk-nyc/e163860
10011.title: New York Charity Walk Committee Members Needed - NYC

10011.description: The Children’s Tumor Foundation is a non-profit organization dedicated to funding critical research that will one day end neurofibromatosis. In addition to benefiting those who live with NF, this research is also shedding new light on several forms of cancer, brain tumors, bone abnormalities, and learning disabilities, ultimately benefiting the broader community. The Children’s Tumor Foundation also supports people living with NF and their families with accurate, current and readily accessible information, and assists in the development of clinical centers to create better access to quality healthcare. We are in need of an event chair to lead our organizational committee! Position Summary: Serve as the Lead Event Organizer, overseeing the event from beginning to end. Organize/recruit, motivate and lead a committee of other volunteers as they recruit teams, obtain sponsorship, and plan the event details. Roles and Responsibilities Work with Operations Chair and Staff Partner to follow all Children’s Tumor Foundation policies and procedures as well as state laws and local ordinances as well as the program standards. Recruit volunteer committee leads to manage the various aspects of the event (such as: Media & Publicity, Logistics, Operations, Recruitment, Event Volunteers). Monitor progress of committee chairs through regular communication to ensure tasks are completed. Enforce accountability with committee members for assigned tasks and the overall event goals. Organizational skills including general organizing, planning, time management, scheduling, coordinating resources and meeting deadlines. Spreadsheet and/or Google Drive knowledge and experience is a plus. Event site: https://join.ctf.org/event/2018-nf-walk-nyc/e163860

10016.description: Thanks so much for wanting to make a difference. We are recruiting volunteers to be group facilitators for children ages 5-17 (groups are divided according to age), as well as event and fundraising helpers. Please view below for the volunteer type requirements and descriptions. The family and children group sessions are held at two Manhattan school locations, midtown and harlem. I invite you to visit our website at www.acaringhand.org to learn more about us and to acquire an application: https://docs.wixstatic.com/ugd/ea9db3_572250eb6e1d4899bd0837d204ffdbe9.pdf. Feel free to contact me directly at RobinGoodman@acaringhand.org for more information or to send A Caring Hand application. View our video about our group program directly at https://vimeo.com/90184263 or on our website, acaringhand.org VOLUNTEER TYPES AND REQUIREMENTS 1) GROUP FACILITATORS: Group facilators must complete an application, have an interview, and attend a 8-12 hour training. One year commitment is required to co-facilitate the child and teen groups. 11 wee group session is held 3 times per year, summer, fall and winter ( Sept - June). A monthly drop in session is held Sept-June. Attendance at a 11 week session is a minimum requirement. In certain circumstances, a commitment for the monthly groups can be accommodated. Group facilitators are assigned to weekly groups during the weekdays and evenings. The days when groups are held vary from season to season. Currently groups are held on Tuesdays and Wednesdays, and our monthly groups are held on Thursdays. Indicate your best evening availability during the week. Groups are held at two Manhattan school locations, midtown and Harlem. 2) VOLUNTEER EVENT HELP: We rely on the generous donations from individuals, corporations, and grants to fund our work. We need a strong volunteer event committe to help with all aspects of our annual gala and other fundraising activities. 3) VOLUNTEER HELPER AND FUNDRAISING: We always need extra hand on deck for various short term projects throughout the year. The projects range from stuffing envelopes and answering phones to doing outreach in th community. Certainly if you have a particular skill aor specific time you would like to help out you should let us know. We also rely on volunteers to help with A Caring Hand, The Billy Esposito Foundation fundraising activities and other board projects. WE WELCOME VOLUNTEERS WITH A RANGE OF EXPERIENCE! APPLY TODAY! Follow this direct link: https://docs.wixstatic.com/ugd/ea9db3_572250eb6e1d4899bd0837d204ffdbe9.pdf or visit our website at www.acaringhand.org for an application.
10016.title: Volunteer Group Facilitators and Event Help Needed!

07701.description: DESCRIPTION: Move for Hunger, a national hunger-relief 501(c)3 organization, seeks a creative, talented, and enthusiastic videography and production intern. The selected candidate will work directly with the Art Director, Executive Director, and Communications Manager to create videos that will help raise awareness about hunger. This is a great opportunity for any self-motivated candidate looking to build their portfolio. TIME COMMITMENT: 2-4 days/week. Minimum 10 hrs/week in our Red Bank office. Part-time availability during the semester. Additional remote hours may be needed for editing. REQUIREMENTS/QUALIFICATIONS: Knowledge and experience with Adobe Premiere & AfterEffects Familiarity with Adobe Photoshop & Illustrator Experience with graphic design a plus** Experience with 2D and/or 3D animation a plus** Must be able to work cohesively and collaborate in a team environment Must be organized, detail oriented, proactive, and deadline-driven A portfolio that showcases your many talents (required with interview) Open to constructive feedback Candidate must use his/her own laptop during the course of the internship - however, extra monitor will be provided Must have a great understanding of our mission, goal, and audience DUTIES & RESPONSIBILITIES: Duties and responsibilities will vary from day to day, however, possibilities include the following: Lead and/or assist with the production of all video and media projects Assist in selecting, organizing, and editing footage Collaborate with other teams to arrange video shoots Produce dynamic content for YouTube & social media channels Produce branded stock video openings & closings Develop storyboard ideas for new content and videos Combine Animation & Video Local off-site shooting Absorb creative direction while bringing unique ideas and a point of view to the table Attend brainstorm sessions and video meetings Adhere to Move For Hunger’s brand and style guide Perform additional administrative tasks as needed, assigned by the Art Director COMPENSATION: This is an Unpaid/Volunteer internship TO APPLY: Please send a cover letter, resume, and portfolio to intern@moveforhunger.org, with the subject line \"VIDEOGRAPHY & PRODUCTION INTERNSHIP\"
07701.title: Videography & Production Internship | Fall 2018

07701.description: DESCRIPTION: Move For Hunger, a national hunger-relief 501(c)3 organization, seeks a dynamic, self-starter interested in learning about new media, also known as social media, communications. This internship is an excellent opportunity to experience how social media is used in a professional, non-profit setting, while working for an exciting young award-winning hunger-relief organization. TIME COMMITMENT Minimum 2-3 days/week Minimum 14 hrs/week in our Red Bank office REQUIREMENTS/QUALIFICATIONS: Freshman, Sophomore, Junior, Senior, or graduate level students, or recent college graduates Preferred Majors: Communication, Journalism, Media Studies, Digital Communication, Public Relations, Marketing, English, Health Studies, Social Work, Public Health, Non-profit Management, Business Administration MS Office Proficiency Social Media Proficiency Excellent written and oral communication skills Outgoing Personality with outstanding interpersonal skills Interest in learning more about social media strategy DUTIES & RESPONSIBILITIES: This position will work directly with the Communications Manager and Director of External Affairs. Duties and responsibilities will vary from day to day, however, possibilities include the following: Assist in planning and executing social media campaigns Identify and track social media coverage Maintain knowledge of current events and trends within hunger relief and food waste fields Assist in developing social media strategies for a variety of goals Amplify website content through social media posts Assist in developing, organizing, and implementing awareness and giving campaigns Assist program directors with operational initiatives and member communications COMPENSATION: This is an Unpaid/Volunteer internship TO APPLY: Please a send cover letter and resume to intern@moveforhunger.org, with the subject line \" NEW MEDIA COMMUNICATIONS INTERNSHIP\"

11439.description: PeerFoward will connect 1.8 million students from low-income communities to college and career over the next decade. We do this by training influential high school students - Peer Leaders - to motivate their classmates over the school year to enroll in college. You can join PeerForward and help train these Peer Leaders at Summer Workshops on college campuses across the nation. Summer Workshops are the cornerstone of the PeerForward program. This is where the transformation occurs from student to Peer Leader. Training includes: Financial Aid 101 Developing a List of Good Fit Colleges Crafting a Personal Statement Four days on a college campus changes the trajectory of a student’s life. Eighty percent of students who attend a Summer Workshop enroll in college. In the past two decades, PeerForward has worked with 250,000 students from over 500 schools across the nation. PeerForward’s peer-to-peer model doubles the likelihood that a low-income student will enroll in college. You can help by volunteering as a Writing Coach or College Coach. For four days, Writing Coaches work in small teams of 8-10 students to jump start the college application process, beginning with the personal statement/essay and College Coaches work one-on-one with 8-10 students to help build a personalized list of good-fit colleges. Writing Coach: https://www.collegesummit.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/VOL-Writing-Coach-2018.pdf College Coach: https://www.collegesummit.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/VOL-College-Coach-2018.pdf By volunteering, you’ll participate in one of the most inspirational weekends of your life, connect to students and other volunteers in your community, receive free room & board for the entire Workshop, and most importantly, empower students from low-income communities to reach their true potential! Workshops will be hosted in Florida, New York, and Maryland. Check out the PeerForward website for specific dates and locations. If you’re interested, you can learn more about PeerFoward at http://www.peerforward.org/volunteer/. You can submit a volunteer application and register for a Workshop at https://college-summit.force.com/Volunteer/CSLogin. If you have any questions, please contact PeerForward’s Volunteer Engagement Coordinator, Jenadra Harvey, at jharvey@collegesummit.org.
11439.title: Connect Low-Income Students to College & Career at St. John's University this Summer!

10004.description: Rescuing Leftover Cuisine, Inc. (\"RLC\") is a non-profit food rescue organization based in New York City that delivers leftover food from restaurants and caterers to local agencies such as homeless shelters and soup kitchens. We have thus far delivered over 1,000,000 pounds of food with the lowest cost per delivery in the industry. Our business model is centered around four stages: (1) proactively seek out businesses with leftover food for partnerships, (2) deliver excess, wholesome food directly to local agencies, (3) use our expertise in food rescue to consult each partner different ways to reduce food waste, (4) partners successfully graduate from the RLC food rescue program with reduced food cost and food waste. Position Summary: The Partner Outreach Intern will learn to develop new relationships with restaurants and other food providers in New York City. You will be represent RLC in communicating with partners and responding to partners’ questions. In order to do this, you will need to manage and understand administrative processes. The Partner Outreach Intern will be help us build professional business relationships with our partners . Responsibilities: Take charge of sales process from beginning to finish, including prospect research, visitation, pitching, and closing deal. Manage tracking database of partners contacted on a weekly basis Updating current partners’ information to our system. Coordinate with volunteers to develop food delivery routes Other duties as assigned RLC interns have the chance to work closely with the founders and have the opportunity to make true, meaningful impact in their time with the organization. All interns will have entry, mid-stage, and final evaluations to further hone the intern’s technical and professional skills. This is a part-time, unpaid internship. Interns are expected to work 20 hours per week. Apply: Interested applicants should apply by submitting a resume to info@rescuingleftovercuisine.org. Candidates for initial phone screenings will be contacted.
10004.title: Partner Outreach Intern

10004.description: Rescuing Leftover Cuisine, Inc. (\"RLC\") is a non-profit food rescue organization based in New York City that delivers leftover food from restaurants and caterers to local agencies such as homeless shelters and soup kitchens. We have thus far delivered over 1,000,000 pounds of food with the lowest cost per delivery in the industry. Our business model is centered around four stages: (1) proactively seek out businesses with leftover food for partnerships, (2) deliver excess, wholesome food directly to local agencies, (3) use our expertise in food rescue to consult each partner different ways to reduce food waste, (4) partners successfully graduate from the RLC food rescue program with reduced food cost and food waste. Position Summary: The Operations Intern will assist with the logistics of pickups and dropoffs between food businesses, volunteers, and charitable organizations in New York City. You will also manage a variety of office tasks to make operations as efficient as possible. You will be properly trained for these tasks. Responsibilities: Contact certain food businesses to confirm pickup times and locations, contact agencies to confirm drop-off times and locations. Maintain volunteer information. Maintain food business details in database. Manage RLC business email account. Assist in organization of special events with community members. Qualifications: Strong organizational skills. Self-motivated; ability to initiate and work independently. Ability to multitask and prioritize. Ability to work quickly to meet the demands of a fast-paced environment. The intern should be creative and always looking for new ways to make our operations more efficient. RLC interns have the chance to work closely with the founders and have the opportunity to make true, meaningful impact in their time with the organization. All interns will have entry, mid-stage, and final evaluations to further hone the intern’s technical and professional skills. This is a part-time, unpaid internship. Interns are expected to work 20 hours per week. May lead to full-time position. Apply: To apply, submit your resume to info@rescuingleftovercuisine.org. Candidates for phone interview will be contacted.
10004.title: Operations Intern

10004.description: Fall 2018 Internship Program Rescuing Leftover Cuisine (\"RLC\") strives to become the world’s most widely used solution for companies and individuals to eliminate food waste in their communities, making food rescue sustainable and universal, and food hunger a thing of the past. RLC is a non-profit food rescue organization based in New York City that delivers leftover food from restaurants and caterers to local agencies such as homeless shelters and soup kitchens in an effort to reduce and eliminate food waste. We have thus far delivered over 480,000 pounds of food with the lowest cost per delivery in the industry. Our business model is centered around four stages: (1) proactively seek out businesses with leftover food and encourage them to donate, (2) deliver excess, wholesome food and bring it directly to homeless shelters and soup kitchens, (3) use our expertise in the food rescue industry to consult each partner different ways to manage inventory / ordering system to reduce food waste, (4) partners successfully graduate from the RLC food rescue program which reduces food waste and saves costs. RLC is currently accepting applications for the Fall 2018 Internship Program. RLC is seeking talented, entrepreneurial, and passionate young leaders with the emotional intelligence and organizational skills needed to work in a self-driven and quality-driven work environment. Position Summary: The Development Program is seeking two Development interns. The Development Interns will assist in forming partnerships with companies for sponsorships, help with formulation of donation campaigns, and provide assistance in arranging fundraising events in New York City. Responsibilities: * Contact corporate groups to establish partnerships and sponsorships * Maintain sponsorship details in database * Gather detailed information regarding charitable organizations * Assist in organization of special events with community members RLC interns have the chance to work closely with the founders and have the opportunity to make true, meaningful impact in their time with the organization. All interns will have entry, mid-stage, and final evaluations to further hone the intern’s technical and professional skills. This is a part-time, unpaid internship. Interns are expected to work 20 hours per week. May lead to full-time position. Qualifications: * Self-starter; ability to initiate and work independently * Ability to interact professionally with potential partners in person, via phone, and email * Ability to multitask and prioritize Apply Interested applicants should apply for a Fall Internship by submitting a resume. Candidates for initial phone screenings will be contacted.
10004.title: Development Intern
